awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR:  Comparative developmental dynamics: single-cell analysis of maize meristem trajectories
awd_abstract_narration:
Maize is one of the most important crops in the United States and plays a major role in the country's food production and its economy. The ability of maize to produce and grow robustly is dependent on growth centers within the plant known as meristems. This study examines two meristem types in detail -- the inflorescence meristem, which ultimately produces all the edible grain, and the root meristem, which forages nutrients and water from the soil. While these meristems are located at opposite ends of the plant, they express many of the same genes and share functional properties. This project takes advantage of new techniques, developed in medical research, called single-cell RNA-sequencing that can dissect an entire organ, like a meristem, one cell at a time, to find which genes are active in a given cell. After such cell-by-cell analysis in root and shoot meristems, the project will use computational techniques to reconstruct each meristem from individual cells, like assembling a tile mosaic. The project will use another set of computational techniques to identify common aspects of gene regulation among cells of the different meristems, analogous to finding common patterns across mosaics. In biological terms, these common patterns represent a core, conserved set of functions that control important traits such as growth. Knowledge of such core gene regulators could be used by breeders to improve traits like grain yield in the shoot and drought resistance in the root. The project will also train junior researchers in these emerging techniques.

Root and shoot meristems are traditionally studied separately, but aspects of their organization are in fact similar. In both root and shoot meristems, pluripotent stem cells signal back and forth with 'organizer' cells (the quiescent center in the root and the organizing center in the shoot) within the stem cell niche. In addition, they share a number of common or paralogous gene regulators. The premise of the project is that a detailed dissection of shoot and root meristems will identify key shared components that control meristem organization and maintenance. In addition, while forward genetics has uncovered many key regulators, genetic redundancy has been a barrier to a more comprehensive understanding of meristems. The project takes advantage of advances in single-cell RNA-seq that now permit a cell-by-cell reconstruction of several different types of shoot and root meristems. A computational analysis will be employed to map equivalent cells among the meristems using the MetaNeighbor approach, accounting for potentially paralogous genes with homologous function across meristems. Machine learning approaches will be used to generate models of the genetic circuitry shared across many or a subset of meristems. The goal is to identify common circuits (and their potentially redundant components) across meristems that could represent a core circuitry needed for the maintenance of meristems. CRISPR knockouts will then be used to test the models of core meristem circuitry, addressing redundancy with guideRNA constructs that target multiple paralogs at once.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project sought a deeper understanding of the genes that control growth and productivity in plants. This collaborative work took advantage of new technologies that enable researchers to essentially take apart the shoot and root growth centers, called meristems, and analyze the active genes in cells one-by-one. This provides powerful information in a number of ways. For example, a gene expressed in a group of cells known to control growth is a strong candidate for a growth regulator that could provide breeding strategies to improve productivity. Very similar genes active in the same cells could indicate that they perform the same function, another valuable piece of information for crop improvement. Overall, the project was highly successful, leading to nine publications, with two in Science, one in Nature, and two in Developmental Cell.

Specifically, the project used single-cell RNA-seq, the readout of active RNAs in single cells, to generate highly resolved “maps” of gene expression in the maize shoot and root. A new map for the developing maize ear—the food production growth center for this key crop—was generated and validated by the Jackson lab. A high-resolution map of the maize root—the primary nutrient and water collecting organ of the plant—was generated by the Birnbaum lab. The Gillis and Shasha labs developed the computational approaches that analyzed these large datasets, which consisted of billions of reads generated by high-throughput sequencing. This led to some key findings about the genes that control important traits. For example, the group showed that a gene called SHORT ROOT had a key role in giving rise to the extra layers of cells in maize root. These cells, called cortex, can help protect the plant against both drought and flooding. In addition, the project analyzed root cells in species related to maize to gain insights into the evolution of traits that allow certain plants to tolerate specific environmental conditions. One key finding was that plant cells tend to “swap” entire genetic programs as they evolve new traits. For example, the project found that a set of genes that produce root secretions known as mucilage or slime, which enable roots to penetrate soil and host beneficial bacteria, moved from epidermal cells in sorghum to root cap cells in maize, a potential adaptation to specific soils. The analysis of the shoot data showed that genes identified in critical locations overlapped with many genes identified by classical quantitative genetics—used in classical breeding—that are critical for maize cob yield. This showed how the gene expression maps generated by the project could be used to improve maize yield.

One of the primary goals of the project was to identify core genes in maize that could control core aspects of growth. In plants, the root meristem arose as an independent growth center from the shoot nearly a billion years ago. Nonetheless, the two meristems share fundamental organizational properties. A central hypothesis of the project is that core regulators in the two meristems might serve a similar role. Or, related genes may serve that role in the two meristems. The final effort in the project combined all the data from root and shoot to search for such core regulators, adapting computational approaches developed by the Gillis lab. The group found many candidate core regulators that are new targets for breeding in maize. In particular, the group analyzed one such candidate called GRASSY TILLERS1 (GT1), which is known to control branching the shoot and was an important gene involved in the domestication of maize. In the root, the group detected that GT1 was a strong candidate for controlling branching in maize roots, an important trait in nutrient collection. Indeed, genetic analysis showed that perturbations of GT1 function led to more root branching. The support of the project’s central hypothesis opens up another new approach for improving crop traits for making them more resilient to modern pressures on agricultural.
